# Dark Factory - Agents MD

# Project Context

- TODO / See README.md

# Git

## Commmiting

- Commit reguarly as features are developed
- Usually try and verify functionality - or at least existing build and/or tests pass before committing.
- Format: `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition section} // {Description, Short} (Optional,Tags)`
- Examples:
  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
- Note the "addition section" is optional. Usually not needed as much, Id say 80/20 -> 60/40 split as the repo grows
- In the longer commit summary - sign - `// Chappie/Model (your model if you know)`

## Branchs and Pushing

- If working with user, commit on current branch, else ask about what branch to use if working auto.
- Don't push unless the user has asked you to for the session. At the very least, ask first.
  - So the user can review, reword or revert commits before they end up on the interwebs.
- `gh` CLI is avalible.

# OpenCode Agents

- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` handles git status/diff review and commits using repo conventions.
- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` tells parent agents when to invoke `@gitter`.

# Dark Factory - Agent Operating Guide

This file is for coding agents working in `dark-factory`.
It captures the current repo reality and the expected conventions as code is added.

## 1) Repository Snapshot (Current State)

- This repository is early-stage and currently docs/config heavy.
- Present top-level tracked files include:
  - `README.md`
  - `TODO.md`
  - `AGENTS.md`
  - `opencode.jsonc`
  - `.opencode/agents/gitter.md`
  - `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md`
- No application source tree is committed yet (`src/`, `apps/`, `crates/`, etc. are absent).
- No build/lint/test config files are present yet (no `Cargo.toml`, root `package.json`, `biome.json`, `eslint` config, etc.).

## 2) Cursor/Copilot Rules

- Checked for Cursor rules:
  - `.cursor/rules/` -> not present
  - `.cursorrules` -> not present
- Checked for Copilot rules:
  - `.github/copilot-instructions.md` -> not present
- Action for agents:
  - If any of these files appear later, treat them as authoritative constraints.
  - Update this `AGENTS.md` section when those rules are added.

## 3) Build, Lint, and Test Commands

Because the repo is currently scaffold-level, there are no project build/test commands to run yet.
Use this section as both current truth and required target conventions for new components.

### 3.1 Current Verified Commands (Now)

- Repo status: `git status`
- Tracked files: `git ls-files`
- No-opcode checks currently available:
  - No root build command
  - No root lint command
  - No root test command
  - No single-test command yet

### 3.2 Required Command Contract (As Code Is Added)

When introducing any runnable component, add scripts/targets that follow this contract.

- JavaScript/TypeScript components (Bun preferred per README):
  - Build all: `bun run build`
  - Lint all: `bun run lint`
  - Typecheck: `bun run typecheck`
  - Test all: `bun run test`
  - Test single file: `bun test path/to/file.test.ts`
  - Test single test name: `bun test --test-name-pattern "name fragment"`

- Rust components:
  - Build all: `cargo build --workspace`
  - Lint all: `cargo clippy --workspace --all-targets -- -D warnings`
  - Test all: `cargo test --workspace`
  - Test single crate: `cargo test -p <crate_name>`
  - Test single test fn: `cargo test <test_name>`
  - Test with output: `cargo test <test_name> -- --nocapture`

- If a monorepo task runner is adopted (`moon`, etc.), ensure wrappers exist:
  - `bun run build` delegates to workspace build
  - `bun run lint` delegates to workspace lint
  - `bun run test` delegates to workspace test
  - Keep single-test passthrough documented in README + this file

### 3.3 CI Expectations for Agents

- Before committing meaningful code changes:
  - Run lint + relevant tests for touched component(s)
  - Prefer running targeted tests first, then broader suites
- For hotfixes or docs-only changes:
  - Run the minimum relevant checks and state what was skipped
- If required toolchain is missing locally:
  - Report exactly what failed and which command was attempted

## 4) Code Style Guidelines

The repo intends to host Bun/TypeScript and Rust components.
Use the following defaults unless local component configs override them.

### 4.1 General Principles

- Prefer clarity over cleverness; write code for future agents and humans.
- Keep functions small and composable; avoid hidden side effects.
- Make invalid states hard to represent (types + validation).
- Favor explicit contracts at module boundaries.
- Avoid TODO debt without context; include owner/scope when leaving TODOs.

### 4.2 Imports and Module Structure (TS)

- Order imports in this sequence:
  1) Node/builtin modules
  2) third-party packages
  3) workspace absolute imports
  4) relative imports
- Keep import groups separated by one blank line.
- Avoid deep relative traversal when an alias exists.
- Do not leave unused imports.
- Prefer named exports over default exports for shared modules.

### 4.3 Formatting

- Respect formatter/linter config once added; do not hand-format against tooling.
- Default TS style (until tool config exists):
  - semicolons on
  - trailing commas where valid
  - single quotes in TS/JS unless framework requires otherwise
  - max line length ~100-120 chars
- Keep markdown concise and task-oriented.

### 4.4 Types and Data Modeling

- TypeScript:
  - Prefer explicit public function return types.
  - Prefer `unknown` over `any`; narrow at boundaries.
  - Use discriminated unions for state machines and outcomes.
  - Avoid non-null assertions (`!`) unless justified inline.
- Rust:
  - Model domain invariants with enums/newtypes where practical.
  - Avoid `unwrap()`/`expect()` in production paths; propagate errors.

### 4.5 Naming Conventions

- Types/classes/components: `PascalCase`
- Functions/variables: `camelCase`
- Constants/env keys: `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE`
- Rust modules/files/functions: idiomatic `snake_case`
- Test names should describe behavior, not implementation details.

### 4.6 Error Handling and Logging

- Never swallow errors silently.
- Add context when rethrowing/propagating (what operation failed and why it matters).
- Return typed/structured errors at service boundaries.
- User-facing surfaces should emit actionable messages, not raw stack traces.
- Logs should be concise and structured where possible; avoid secrets in logs.

### 4.7 Testing Conventions

- Co-locate tests by component/module unless framework strongly prefers otherwise.
- Cover happy path, edge path, and failure path for new logic.
- For regressions, add a test that fails before fix and passes after.
- Prefer deterministic tests; avoid real network/time randomness unless explicitly integration-level.

## 5) Git Workflow and Commit Rules

- Commit regularly as meaningful units are completed.
- Try to verify relevant build/lint/test commands before committing.
- Commit message format:
  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
- Examples:
  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
- Optional addition section is encouraged only when it adds clarity.
- Include a short rationale in commit body and sign with agent/model when possible:
  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`

## 6) Branching and Pushing

- If collaborating with a user in-session, commit on current branch unless directed otherwise.
- If working autonomously outside direct user direction, clarify intended branch strategy first.
- Do not push unless explicitly requested in-session.
- `gh` CLI is available for PR workflows once code exists.

## 7) OpenCode Agent Integration

- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` handles git status/diff review and commits.
- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` tells parent agents when to invoke `@gitter`.
- Use `@gitter` when user asks for commit help or when changes should be grouped cleanly.

## 8) Keeping This File Fresh

- Update this file whenever build/test tooling is introduced or changed.
- Keep command examples executable and component-specific.
- If a local tool config conflicts with this file, local config wins; then patch this file.

Please analyze this codebase and create an AGENTS.md file containing:
1. Build/lint/test commands - especially for running a single test
2. Code style guidelines including imports, formatting, types, naming conventions, error handling, etc.

The file you create will be given to agentic coding agents (such as yourself) that operate in this repository. Make it about 150 lines long.
If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include them.

If there's already an AGENTS.md, improve it if it's located in /Users/alex/repos/vfp/dark-factory

# Dark Factory - Autonomous Agentic Development At Scale

# Concept

- A central `dark-factory` "core" is used to track `worlds`
- A `world` is an `env` + `actor`(s)
- `env` is like a project and represents where an `actor` is spawned.
  - Similar to `projets` in OpenCode or other agent orchestrators
  - `env` may be a directory on host (simplest and most common) or later expanded to:
    - Remote directory on a SSH-connected machine
    - Dockershell w/ virutal FS
    - Git Worktree
- `world` can link multiple `envs` - which assume to all be multiple versions of the same root project
  - we call this concept `dimensions`
  - Examples:
    - Multiple cloned directories of the same root project
    - Git worktree supportds
    - Instanced Docker shells
- When an agent is spawned - it is linked to a given env
  - Linking can just be spawning the agent at the directory (IE: `opencode .`)

+# Dark Factory - Agent Operating Guide
+
+This file is for coding agents working in `dark-factory`.
+It captures the current repo reality and the expected conventions as code is added.
+
+## 1) Repository Snapshot (Current State)
+
+- This repository is early-stage and currently docs/config heavy.
+- Present top-level tracked files include:
+  - `README.md`
+  - `TODO.md`
+  - `AGENTS.md`
+  - `opencode.jsonc`
+  - `.opencode/agents/gitter.md`
+  - `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md`
+- No application source tree is committed yet (`src/`, `apps/`, `crates/`, etc. are absent).
+- No build/lint/test config files are present yet (no `Cargo.toml`, root `package.json`, `biome.json`, `eslint` config, etc.).
+
+## 2) Cursor/Copilot Rules
+
+- Checked for Cursor rules:
+  - `.cursor/rules/` -> not present
+  - `.cursorrules` -> not present
+- Checked for Copilot rules:
+  - `.github/copilot-instructions.md` -> not present
+- Action for agents:
+  - If any of these files appear later, treat them as authoritative constraints.
+  - Update this `AGENTS.md` section when those rules are added.
+
+## 3) Build, Lint, and Test Commands
+
+Because the repo is currently scaffold-level, there are no project build/test commands to run yet.
+Use this section as both current truth and required target conventions for new components.
+
+### 3.1 Current Verified Commands (Now)
+
+- Repo status: `git status`
+- Tracked files: `git ls-files`
+- No-opcode checks currently available:
+  - No root build command
+  - No root lint command
+  - No root test command
+  - No single-test command yet
+
+### 3.2 Required Command Contract (As Code Is Added)
+
+When introducing any runnable component, add scripts/targets that follow this contract.
+
+- JavaScript/TypeScript components (Bun preferred per README):
+  - Build all: `bun run build`
+  - Lint all: `bun run lint`
+  - Typecheck: `bun run typecheck`
+  - Test all: `bun run test`
+  - Test single file: `bun test path/to/file.test.ts`
+  - Test single test name: `bun test --test-name-pattern "name fragment"`
+
+- Rust components:
+  - Build all: `cargo build --workspace`
+  - Lint all: `cargo clippy --workspace --all-targets -- -D warnings`
+  - Test all: `cargo test --workspace`
+  - Test single crate: `cargo test -p <crate_name>`
+  - Test single test fn: `cargo test <test_name>`
+  - Test with output: `cargo test <test_name> -- --nocapture`
+
+- If a monorepo task runner is adopted (`moon`, etc.), ensure wrappers exist:
+  - `bun run build` delegates to workspace build
+  - `bun run lint` delegates to workspace lint
+  - `bun run test` delegates to workspace test
+  - Keep single-test passthrough documented in README + this file
+
+### 3.3 CI Expectations for Agents
+
+- Before committing meaningful code changes:
+  - Run lint + relevant tests for touched component(s)
+  - Prefer running targeted tests first, then broader suites
+- For hotfixes or docs-only changes:
+  - Run the minimum relevant checks and state what was skipped
+- If required toolchain is missing locally:
+  - Report exactly what failed and which command was attempted
+
+## 4) Code Style Guidelines
+
+The repo intends to host Bun/TypeScript and Rust components.
+Use the following defaults unless local component configs override them.
+
+### 4.1 General Principles
+
+- Prefer clarity over cleverness; write code for future agents and humans.
+- Keep functions small and composable; avoid hidden side effects.
+- Make invalid states hard to represent (types + validation).
+- Favor explicit contracts at module boundaries.
+- Avoid TODO debt without context; include owner/scope when leaving TODOs.
+
+### 4.2 Imports and Module Structure (TS)
+
+- Order imports in this sequence:
+  1) Node/builtin modules
+  2) third-party packages
+  3) workspace absolute imports
+  4) relative imports
+- Keep import groups separated by one blank line.
+- Avoid deep relative traversal when an alias exists.
+- Do not leave unused imports.
+- Prefer named exports over default exports for shared modules.
+
+### 4.3 Formatting
+
+- Respect formatter/linter config once added; do not hand-format against tooling.
+- Default TS style (until tool config exists):
+  - semicolons on
+  - trailing commas where valid
+  - single quotes in TS/JS unless framework requires otherwise
+  - max line length ~100-120 chars
+- Keep markdown concise and task-oriented.
+
+### 4.4 Types and Data Modeling
+
+- TypeScript:
+  - Prefer explicit public function return types.
+  - Prefer `unknown` over `any`; narrow at boundaries.
+  - Use discriminated unions for state machines and outcomes.
+  - Avoid non-null assertions (`!`) unless justified inline.
+- Rust:
+  - Model domain invariants with enums/newtypes where practical.
+  - Avoid `unwrap()`/`expect()` in production paths; propagate errors.
+
+### 4.5 Naming Conventions
+
+- Types/classes/components: `PascalCase`
+- Functions/variables: `camelCase`
+- Constants/env keys: `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE`
+- Rust modules/files/functions: idiomatic `snake_case`
+- Test names should describe behavior, not implementation details.
+
+### 4.6 Error Handling and Logging
+
+- Never swallow errors silently.
+- Add context when rethrowing/propagating (what operation failed and why it matters).
+- Return typed/structured errors at service boundaries.
+- User-facing surfaces should emit actionable messages, not raw stack traces.
+- Logs should be concise and structured where possible; avoid secrets in logs.
+
+### 4.7 Testing Conventions
+
+- Co-locate tests by component/module unless framework strongly prefers otherwise.
+- Cover happy path, edge path, and failure path for new logic.
+- For regressions, add a test that fails before fix and passes after.
+- Prefer deterministic tests; avoid real network/time randomness unless explicitly integration-level.
+
+## 5) Git Workflow and Commit Rules
+
+- Commit regularly as meaningful units are completed.
+- Try to verify relevant build/lint/test commands before committing.
+- Commit message format:
+  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
+- Examples:
+  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
+  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
+- Optional addition section is encouraged only when it adds clarity.
+- Include a short rationale in commit body and sign with agent/model when possible:
+  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`
+
+## 6) Branching and Pushing
+
+- If collaborating with a user in-session, commit on current branch unless directed otherwise.
+- If working autonomously outside direct user direction, clarify intended branch strategy first.
+- Do not push unless explicitly requested in-session.
+- `gh` CLI is available for PR workflows once code exists.
+
+## 7) OpenCode Agent Integration
+
+- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` handles git status/diff review and commits.
+- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` tells parent agents when to invoke `@gitter`.
+- Use `@gitter` when user asks for commit help or when changes should be grouped cleanly.
+
+## 8) Keeping This File Fresh
+
+- Update this file whenever build/test tooling is introduced or changed.
+- Keep command examples executable and component-specific.
+- If a local tool config conflicts with this file, local config wins; then patch this file.
*** End Patch

# Dark Factory - Agent Operating Guide

This file is for coding agents working in `dark-factory`.
It captures the current repo reality and the expected conventions as code is added.

## 1) Repository Snapshot (Current State)

- This repository is early-stage and currently docs/config heavy.
- Present top-level tracked files include:
  - `README.md`
  - `TODO.md`
  - `AGENTS.md`
  - `opencode.jsonc`
  - `.opencode/agents/gitter.md`
  - `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md`
- No application source tree is committed yet (`src/`, `apps/`, `crates/`, etc. are absent).
- No build/lint/test config files are present yet (no `Cargo.toml`, root `package.json`, `biome.json`, `eslint` config, etc.).

## 2) Cursor/Copilot Rules

- Checked for Cursor rules:
  - `.cursor/rules/` -> not present
  - `.cursorrules` -> not present
- Checked for Copilot rules:
  - `.github/copilot-instructions.md` -> not present
- Action for agents:
  - If any of these files appear later, treat them as authoritative constraints.
  - Update this `AGENTS.md` section when those rules are added.

## 3) Build, Lint, and Test Commands

Because the repo is currently scaffold-level, there are no project build/test commands to run yet.
Use this section as both current truth and required target conventions for new components.

### 3.1 Current Verified Commands (Now)

- Repo status: `git status`
- Tracked files: `git ls-files`
- No-opcode checks currently available:
  - No root build command
  - No root lint command
  - No root test command
  - No single-test command yet

### 3.2 Required Command Contract (As Code Is Added)

When introducing any runnable component, add scripts/targets that follow this contract.

- JavaScript/TypeScript components (Bun preferred per README):
  - Build all: `bun run build`
  - Lint all: `bun run lint`
  - Typecheck: `bun run typecheck`
  - Test all: `bun run test`
  - Test single file: `bun test path/to/file.test.ts`
  - Test single test name: `bun test --test-name-pattern "name fragment"`

- Rust components:
  - Build all: `cargo build --workspace`
  - Lint all: `cargo clippy --workspace --all-targets -- -D warnings`
  - Test all: `cargo test --workspace`
  - Test single crate: `cargo test -p <crate_name>`
  - Test single test fn: `cargo test <test_name>`
  - Test with output: `cargo test <test_name> -- --nocapture`

- If a monorepo task runner is adopted (`moon`, etc.), ensure wrappers exist:
  - `bun run build` delegates to workspace build
  - `bun run lint` delegates to workspace lint
  - `bun run test` delegates to workspace test
  - Keep single-test passthrough documented in README + this file

### 3.3 CI Expectations for Agents

- Before committing meaningful code changes:
  - Run lint + relevant tests for touched component(s)
  - Prefer running targeted tests first, then broader suites
- For hotfixes or docs-only changes:
  - Run the minimum relevant checks and state what was skipped
- If required toolchain is missing locally:
  - Report exactly what failed and which command was attempted

## 4) Code Style Guidelines

The repo intends to host Bun/TypeScript and Rust components.
Use the following defaults unless local component configs override them.

### 4.1 General Principles

- Prefer clarity over cleverness; write code for future agents and humans.
- Keep functions small and composable; avoid hidden side effects.
- Make invalid states hard to represent (types + validation).
- Favor explicit contracts at module boundaries.
- Avoid TODO debt without context; include owner/scope when leaving TODOs.

### 4.2 Imports and Module Structure (TS)

- Order imports in this sequence:
  1) Node/builtin modules
  2) third-party packages
  3) workspace absolute imports
  4) relative imports
- Keep import groups separated by one blank line.
- Avoid deep relative traversal when an alias exists.
- Do not leave unused imports.
- Prefer named exports over default exports for shared modules.

### 4.3 Formatting

- Respect formatter/linter config once added; do not hand-format against tooling.
- Default TS style (until tool config exists):
  - semicolons on
  - trailing commas where valid
  - single quotes in TS/JS unless framework requires otherwise
  - max line length ~100-120 chars
- Keep markdown concise and task-oriented.

### 4.4 Types and Data Modeling

- TypeScript:
  - Prefer explicit public function return types.
  - Prefer `unknown` over `any`; narrow at boundaries.
  - Use discriminated unions for state machines and outcomes.
  - Avoid non-null assertions (`!`) unless justified inline.
- Rust:
  - Model domain invariants with enums/newtypes where practical.
  - Avoid `unwrap()`/`expect()` in production paths; propagate errors.

### 4.5 Naming Conventions

- Types/classes/components: `PascalCase`
- Functions/variables: `camelCase`
- Constants/env keys: `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE`
- Rust modules/files/functions: idiomatic `snake_case`
- Test names should describe behavior, not implementation details.

### 4.6 Error Handling and Logging

- Never swallow errors silently.
- Add context when rethrowing/propagating (what operation failed and why it matters).
- Return typed/structured errors at service boundaries.
- User-facing surfaces should emit actionable messages, not raw stack traces.
- Logs should be concise and structured where possible; avoid secrets in logs.

### 4.7 Testing Conventions

- Co-locate tests by component/module unless framework strongly prefers otherwise.
- Cover happy path, edge path, and failure path for new logic.
- For regressions, add a test that fails before fix and passes after.
- Prefer deterministic tests; avoid real network/time randomness unless explicitly integration-level.

## 5) Git Workflow and Commit Rules

- Commit regularly as meaningful units are completed.
- Try to verify relevant build/lint/test commands before committing.
- Commit message format:
  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
- Examples:
  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
- Optional addition section is encouraged only when it adds clarity.
- Include a short rationale in commit body and sign with agent/model when possible:
  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`

## 6) Branching and Pushing

- If collaborating with a user in-session, commit on current branch unless directed otherwise.
- If working autonomously outside direct user direction, clarify intended branch strategy first.
- Do not push unless explicitly requested in-session.
- `gh` CLI is available for PR workflows once code exists.

## 7) OpenCode Agent Integration

- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` handles git status/diff review and commits.
- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` tells parent agents when to invoke `@gitter`.
- Use `@gitter` when user asks for commit help or when changes should be grouped cleanly.

## 8) Keeping This File Fresh

- Update this file whenever build/test tooling is introduced or changed.
- Keep command examples executable and component-specific.
- If a local tool config conflicts with this file, local config wins; then patch this file.

# Dark Factory - Agent Operating Guide

This file is for coding agents working in `dark-factory`.
It captures the current repo reality and the expected conventions as code is added.

## 1) Repository Snapshot (Current State)

- This repository is early-stage and currently docs/config heavy.
- Present top-level tracked files include:
  - `README.md`
  - `TODO.md`
  - `AGENTS.md`
  - `opencode.jsonc`
  - `.opencode/agents/gitter.md`
  - `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md`
- No application source tree is committed yet (`src/`, `apps/`, `crates/`, etc. are absent).
- No build/lint/test config files are present yet (no `Cargo.toml`, root `package.json`, `biome.json`, `eslint` config, etc.).

## 2) Cursor/Copilot Rules

- Checked for Cursor rules:
  - `.cursor/rules/` -> not present
  - `.cursorrules` -> not present
- Checked for Copilot rules:
  - `.github/copilot-instructions.md` -> not present
- Action for agents:
  - If any of these files appear later, treat them as authoritative constraints.
  - Update this `AGENTS.md` section when those rules are added.

## 3) Build, Lint, and Test Commands

Because the repo is currently scaffold-level, there are no project build/test commands to run yet.
Use this section as both current truth and required target conventions for new components.

### 3.1 Current Verified Commands (Now)

- Repo status: `git status`
- Tracked files: `git ls-files`
- No-opcode checks currently available:
  - No root build command
  - No root lint command
  - No root test command
  - No single-test command yet

### 3.2 Required Command Contract (As Code Is Added)

When introducing any runnable component, add scripts/targets that follow this contract.

- JavaScript/TypeScript components (Bun preferred per README):
  - Build all: `bun run build`
  - Lint all: `bun run lint`
  - Typecheck: `bun run typecheck`
  - Test all: `bun run test`
  - Test single file: `bun test path/to/file.test.ts`
  - Test single test name: `bun test --test-name-pattern "name fragment"`

- Rust components:
  - Build all: `cargo build --workspace`
  - Lint all: `cargo clippy --workspace --all-targets -- -D warnings`
  - Test all: `cargo test --workspace`
  - Test single crate: `cargo test -p <crate_name>`
  - Test single test fn: `cargo test <test_name>`
  - Test with output: `cargo test <test_name> -- --nocapture`

- If a monorepo task runner is adopted (`moon`, etc.), ensure wrappers exist:
  - `bun run build` delegates to workspace build
  - `bun run lint` delegates to workspace lint
  - `bun run test` delegates to workspace test
  - Keep single-test passthrough documented in README + this file

### 3.3 CI Expectations for Agents

- Before committing meaningful code changes:
  - Run lint + relevant tests for touched component(s)
  - Prefer running targeted tests first, then broader suites
- For hotfixes or docs-only changes:
  - Run the minimum relevant checks and state what was skipped
- If required toolchain is missing locally:
  - Report exactly what failed and which command was attempted

## 4) Code Style Guidelines

The repo intends to host Bun/TypeScript and Rust components.
Use the following defaults unless local component configs override them.

### 4.1 General Principles

- Prefer clarity over cleverness; write code for future agents and humans.
- Keep functions small and composable; avoid hidden side effects.
- Make invalid states hard to represent (types + validation).
- Favor explicit contracts at module boundaries.
- Avoid TODO debt without context; include owner/scope when leaving TODOs.

### 4.2 Imports and Module Structure (TS)

- Order imports in this sequence:
  1) Node/builtin modules
  2) third-party packages
  3) workspace absolute imports
  4) relative imports
- Keep import groups separated by one blank line.
- Avoid deep relative traversal when an alias exists.
- Do not leave unused imports.
- Prefer named exports over default exports for shared modules.

### 4.3 Formatting

- Respect formatter/linter config once added; do not hand-format against tooling.
- Default TS style (until tool config exists):
  - semicolons on
  - trailing commas where valid
  - single quotes in TS/JS unless framework requires otherwise
  - max line length ~100-120 chars
- Keep markdown concise and task-oriented.

### 4.4 Types and Data Modeling

- TypeScript:
  - Prefer explicit public function return types.
  - Prefer `unknown` over `any`; narrow at boundaries.
  - Use discriminated unions for state machines and outcomes.
  - Avoid non-null assertions (`!`) unless justified inline.
- Rust:
  - Model domain invariants with enums/newtypes where practical.
  - Avoid `unwrap()`/`expect()` in production paths; propagate errors.

### 4.5 Naming Conventions

- Types/classes/components: `PascalCase`
- Functions/variables: `camelCase`
- Constants/env keys: `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE`
- Rust modules/files/functions: idiomatic `snake_case`
- Test names should describe behavior, not implementation details.

### 4.6 Error Handling and Logging

- Never swallow errors silently.
- Add context when rethrowing/propagating (what operation failed and why it matters).
- Return typed/structured errors at service boundaries.
- User-facing surfaces should emit actionable messages, not raw stack traces.
- Logs should be concise and structured where possible; avoid secrets in logs.

### 4.7 Testing Conventions

- Co-locate tests by component/module unless framework strongly prefers otherwise.
- Cover happy path, edge path, and failure path for new logic.
- For regressions, add a test that fails before fix and passes after.
- Prefer deterministic tests; avoid real network/time randomness unless explicitly integration-level.

## 5) Git Workflow and Commit Rules

- Commit regularly as meaningful units are completed.
- Try to verify relevant build/lint/test commands before committing.
- Commit message format:
  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
- Examples:
  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
- Optional addition section is encouraged only when it adds clarity.
- Include a short rationale in commit body and sign with agent/model when possible:
  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`

## 6) Branching and Pushing

- If collaborating with a user in-session, commit on current branch unless directed otherwise.
- If working autonomously outside direct user direction, clarify intended branch strategy first.
- Do not push unless explicitly requested in-session.
- `gh` CLI is available for PR workflows once code exists.

## 7) OpenCode Agent Integration

- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` handles git status/diff review and commits.
- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` tells parent agents when to invoke `@gitter`.
- Use `@gitter` when user asks for commit help or when changes should be grouped cleanly.

## 8) Keeping This File Fresh

- Update this file whenever build/test tooling is introduced or changed.
- Keep command examples executable and component-specific.
- If a local tool config conflicts with this file, local config wins; then patch this file.

This file is for coding agents working in `dark-factory`.
It reflects only what is currently true in this repository.

- Do not invent or assume project commands in commits or PR notes.
- If new tooling is added, document only commands that are verified in this repo.

## 3) Cursor and Copilot Rules

- Checked and currently absent:
  - `.cursor/rules/`
  - `.cursorrules`
  - `.github/copilot-instructions.md`
- If any of these files appear later, treat them as authoritative and update this guide.

## 4) Coding Style (Minimal Baseline)

Until language/tool-specific configs exist, follow pragmatic defaults:

- Favor readable, explicit code over clever shortcuts.
- Keep functions focused and avoid hidden side effects.
- Avoid dead code, unused imports, and speculative abstractions.
- Keep naming consistent (`PascalCase` types, `camelCase` values/functions, `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE` constants).
- Handle errors with context; do not swallow exceptions silently.
- Never log secrets or credentials.

## 5) Git Workflow

- Commit meaningful units of work; avoid giant mixed commits.
- Do not push unless the user explicitly requests it.
- Commit message format:
  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
- Examples:
  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
- In commit body, add a short rationale and signature when possible:
  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`

## 6) OpenCode Integration

- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` is the git-focused subagent.
- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` documents when to route commit tasks to `@gitter`.
- Use `@gitter` when the user asks for commit support or cleanup.

## 7) Keep This File Updated

- Update this file when real code, tooling, or CI is added.
- Keep instructions tied to verified repository behavior.
- Prefer short, accurate guidance over aspirational process docs.

-  - Update this `AGENTS.md` section when those rules are added.
-
-## 3) Build, Lint, and Test Commands
-
-Because the repo is currently scaffold-level, there are no project build/test commands to run yet.
-Use this section as both current truth and required target conventions for new components.
-
-### 3.1 Current Verified Commands (Now)
-
-- Repo status: `git status`
-- Tracked files: `git ls-files`
-- No-opcode checks currently available:
-  - No root build command
-  - No root lint command
-  - No root test command
-  - No single-test command yet
-
-### 3.2 Required Command Contract (As Code Is Added)
-
-When introducing any runnable component, add scripts/targets that follow this contract.
-
-- JavaScript/TypeScript components (Bun preferred per README):
-  - Build all: `bun run build`
-  - Lint all: `bun run lint`
-  - Typecheck: `bun run typecheck`
-  - Test all: `bun run test`
-  - Test single file: `bun test path/to/file.test.ts`
-  - Test single test name: `bun test --test-name-pattern "name fragment"`
-
-- Rust components:
-  - Build all: `cargo build --workspace`
-  - Lint all: `cargo clippy --workspace --all-targets -- -D warnings`
-  - Test all: `cargo test --workspace`
-  - Test single crate: `cargo test -p <crate_name>`
-  - Test single test fn: `cargo test <test_name>`
-  - Test with output: `cargo test <test_name> -- --nocapture`
-
-- If a monorepo task runner is adopted (`moon`, etc.), ensure wrappers exist:
-  - `bun run build` delegates to workspace build
-  - `bun run lint` delegates to workspace lint
-  - `bun run test` delegates to workspace test
-  - Keep single-test passthrough documented in README + this file
-
-### 3.3 CI Expectations for Agents
-
-- Before committing meaningful code changes:
-  - Run lint + relevant tests for touched component(s)
-  - Prefer running targeted tests first, then broader suites
-- For hotfixes or docs-only changes:
-  - Run the minimum relevant checks and state what was skipped
-- If required toolchain is missing locally:
-  - Report exactly what failed and which command was attempted
-
-## 4) Code Style Guidelines
-
-The repo intends to host Bun/TypeScript and Rust components.
-Use the following defaults unless local component configs override them.
-
-### 4.1 General Principles
-
-- Prefer clarity over cleverness; write code for future agents and humans.
-- Keep functions small and composable; avoid hidden side effects.
-- Make invalid states hard to represent (types + validation).
-- Favor explicit contracts at module boundaries.
-- Avoid TODO debt without context; include owner/scope when leaving TODOs.
-
-### 4.2 Imports and Module Structure (TS)
-
-- Order imports in this sequence:
-  1) Node/builtin modules
-  2) third-party packages
-  3) workspace absolute imports
-  4) relative imports
-- Keep import groups separated by one blank line.
-- Avoid deep relative traversal when an alias exists.
-- Do not leave unused imports.
-- Prefer named exports over default exports for shared modules.
-
-### 4.3 Formatting
-
-- Respect formatter/linter config once added; do not hand-format against tooling.
-- Default TS style (until tool config exists):
-  - semicolons on
-  - trailing commas where valid
-  - single quotes in TS/JS unless framework requires otherwise
-  - max line length ~100-120 chars
-- Keep markdown concise and task-oriented.
-
-### 4.4 Types and Data Modeling
-
-- TypeScript:
-  - Prefer explicit public function return types.
-  - Prefer `unknown` over `any`; narrow at boundaries.
-  - Use discriminated unions for state machines and outcomes.
-  - Avoid non-null assertions (`!`) unless justified inline.
-- Rust:
-  - Model domain invariants with enums/newtypes where practical.
-  - Avoid `unwrap()`/`expect()` in production paths; propagate errors.
-
-### 4.5 Naming Conventions
-
-- Types/classes/components: `PascalCase`
-- Functions/variables: `camelCase`
-- Constants/env keys: `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE`
-- Rust modules/files/functions: idiomatic `snake_case`
-- Test names should describe behavior, not implementation details.
-
-### 4.6 Error Handling and Logging
-
-- Never swallow errors silently.
-- Add context when rethrowing/propagating (what operation failed and why it matters).
-- Return typed/structured errors at service boundaries.
-- User-facing surfaces should emit actionable messages, not raw stack traces.
-- Logs should be concise and structured where possible; avoid secrets in logs.
-
-### 4.7 Testing Conventions
-
-- Co-locate tests by component/module unless framework strongly prefers otherwise.
-- Cover happy path, edge path, and failure path for new logic.
-- For regressions, add a test that fails before fix and passes after.
-- Prefer deterministic tests; avoid real network/time randomness unless explicitly integration-level.
-
-## 5) Git Workflow and Commit Rules
-
-- Commit regularly as meaningful units are completed.
-- Try to verify relevant build/lint/test commands before committing.
-- Commit message format:
-  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
-- Examples:
-  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
-  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
-- Optional addition section is encouraged only when it adds clarity.
-- Include a short rationale in commit body and sign with agent/model when possible:
-  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`
-
-## 6) Branching and Pushing
-
-- If collaborating with a user in-session, commit on current branch unless directed otherwise.
-- If working autonomously outside direct user direction, clarify intended branch strategy first.
-- Do not push unless explicitly requested in-session.
-- `gh` CLI is available for PR workflows once code exists.
-
-## 7) OpenCode Agent Integration
-
-- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` handles git status/diff review and commits.
-- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` tells parent agents when to invoke `@gitter`.
-- Use `@gitter` when user asks for commit help or when changes should be grouped cleanly.
-
-## 8) Keeping This File Fresh
-
-- Update this file whenever build/test tooling is introduced or changed.
-- Keep command examples executable and component-specific.
-- If a local tool config conflicts with this file, local config wins; then patch this file.

+
+- There are no validated build, lint, typecheck, or test commands yet.
+- Do not invent or assume project commands in commits or PR notes.
+- If new tooling is added, document only commands that are verified in this repo.

+

+  - `.cursor/rules/`
+  - `.cursorrules`
+  - `.github/copilot-instructions.md`
+- If any of these files appear later, treat them as authoritative and update this guide.

+
+Until language/tool-specific configs exist, follow pragmatic defaults:
+
+- Favor readable, explicit code over clever shortcuts.
+- Keep functions focused and avoid hidden side effects.
+- Avoid dead code, unused imports, and speculative abstractions.
+- Keep naming consistent (`PascalCase` types, `camelCase` values/functions, `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE` constants).
+- Handle errors with context; do not swallow exceptions silently.
+- Never log secrets or credentials.
+
+## 5) Git Workflow
+
+- Commit meaningful units of work; avoid giant mixed commits.
+- Do not push unless the user explicitly requests it.
+- Commit message format:
+  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
+- Examples:
+  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
+  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
+- In commit body, add a short rationale and signature when possible:
+  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`
+
+## 6) OpenCode Integration
+
+- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` is the git-focused subagent.
+- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` documents when to route commit tasks to `@gitter`.
+- Use `@gitter` when the user asks for commit support or cleanup.
+

+
+- Update this file when real code, tooling, or CI is added.
+- Keep instructions tied to verified repository behavior.
+- Prefer short, accurate guidance over aspirational process docs.

# Dark Factory - Agent Operating Guide

This file is for coding agents working in `dark-factory`.
It captures the current repo reality and the expected conventions as code is added.

## 1) Repository Snapshot (Current State)

- This repository is early-stage and currently docs/config heavy.
- Present top-level tracked files include:
  - `README.md`
  - `TODO.md`
  - `AGENTS.md`
  - `opencode.jsonc`
  - `.opencode/agents/gitter.md`
  - `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md`
- No application source tree is committed yet (`src/`, `apps/`, `crates/`, etc. are absent).
- No build/lint/test config files are present yet (no `Cargo.toml`, root `package.json`, `biome.json`, `eslint` config, etc.).

## 2) Cursor/Copilot Rules

- Checked for Cursor rules:
  - `.cursor/rules/` -> not present
  - `.cursorrules` -> not present
- Checked for Copilot rules:
  - `.github/copilot-instructions.md` -> not present
- Action for agents:
  - If any of these files appear later, treat them as authoritative constraints.
  - Update this `AGENTS.md` section when those rules are added.

## 3) Build, Lint, and Test Commands

Because the repo is currently scaffold-level, there are no project build/test commands to run yet.
Use this section as both current truth and required target conventions for new components.

### 3.1 Current Verified Commands (Now)

- Repo status: `git status`
- Tracked files: `git ls-files`
- No-opcode checks currently available:
  - No root build command
  - No root lint command
  - No root test command
  - No single-test command yet

### 3.2 Required Command Contract (As Code Is Added)

When introducing any runnable component, add scripts/targets that follow this contract.

- JavaScript/TypeScript components (Bun preferred per README):
  - Build all: `bun run build`
  - Lint all: `bun run lint`
  - Typecheck: `bun run typecheck`
  - Test all: `bun run test`
  - Test single file: `bun test path/to/file.test.ts`
  - Test single test name: `bun test --test-name-pattern "name fragment"`

- Rust components:
  - Build all: `cargo build --workspace`
  - Lint all: `cargo clippy --workspace --all-targets -- -D warnings`
  - Test all: `cargo test --workspace`
  - Test single crate: `cargo test -p <crate_name>`
  - Test single test fn: `cargo test <test_name>`
  - Test with output: `cargo test <test_name> -- --nocapture`

- If a monorepo task runner is adopted (`moon`, etc.), ensure wrappers exist:
  - `bun run build` delegates to workspace build
  - `bun run lint` delegates to workspace lint
  - `bun run test` delegates to workspace test
  - Keep single-test passthrough documented in README + this file

### 3.3 CI Expectations for Agents

- Before committing meaningful code changes:
  - Run lint + relevant tests for touched component(s)
  - Prefer running targeted tests first, then broader suites
- For hotfixes or docs-only changes:
  - Run the minimum relevant checks and state what was skipped
- If required toolchain is missing locally:
  - Report exactly what failed and which command was attempted

## 4) Code Style Guidelines

The repo intends to host Bun/TypeScript and Rust components.
Use the following defaults unless local component configs override them.

### 4.1 General Principles

- Prefer clarity over cleverness; write code for future agents and humans.
- Keep functions small and composable; avoid hidden side effects.
- Make invalid states hard to represent (types + validation).
- Favor explicit contracts at module boundaries.
- Avoid TODO debt without context; include owner/scope when leaving TODOs.

### 4.2 Imports and Module Structure (TS)

- Order imports in this sequence:
  1) Node/builtin modules
  2) third-party packages
  3) workspace absolute imports
  4) relative imports
- Keep import groups separated by one blank line.
- Avoid deep relative traversal when an alias exists.
- Do not leave unused imports.
- Prefer named exports over default exports for shared modules.

### 4.3 Formatting

- Respect formatter/linter config once added; do not hand-format against tooling.
- Default TS style (until tool config exists):
  - semicolons on
  - trailing commas where valid
  - single quotes in TS/JS unless framework requires otherwise
  - max line length ~100-120 chars
- Keep markdown concise and task-oriented.

### 4.4 Types and Data Modeling

- TypeScript:
  - Prefer explicit public function return types.
  - Prefer `unknown` over `any`; narrow at boundaries.
  - Use discriminated unions for state machines and outcomes.
  - Avoid non-null assertions (`!`) unless justified inline.
- Rust:
  - Model domain invariants with enums/newtypes where practical.
  - Avoid `unwrap()`/`expect()` in production paths; propagate errors.

### 4.5 Naming Conventions

- Types/classes/components: `PascalCase`
- Functions/variables: `camelCase`
- Constants/env keys: `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE`
- Rust modules/files/functions: idiomatic `snake_case`
- Test names should describe behavior, not implementation details.

### 4.6 Error Handling and Logging

- Never swallow errors silently.
- Add context when rethrowing/propagating (what operation failed and why it matters).
- Return typed/structured errors at service boundaries.
- User-facing surfaces should emit actionable messages, not raw stack traces.
- Logs should be concise and structured where possible; avoid secrets in logs.

### 4.7 Testing Conventions

- Co-locate tests by component/module unless framework strongly prefers otherwise.
- Cover happy path, edge path, and failure path for new logic.
- For regressions, add a test that fails before fix and passes after.
- Prefer deterministic tests; avoid real network/time randomness unless explicitly integration-level.

## 5) Git Workflow and Commit Rules

- Commit regularly as meaningful units are completed.
- Try to verify relevant build/lint/test commands before committing.
- Commit message format:
  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
- Examples:
  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
- Optional addition section is encouraged only when it adds clarity.
- Include a short rationale in commit body and sign with agent/model when possible:
  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`

## 6) Branching and Pushing

- If collaborating with a user in-session, commit on current branch unless directed otherwise.
- If working autonomously outside direct user direction, clarify intended branch strategy first.
- Do not push unless explicitly requested in-session.
- `gh` CLI is available for PR workflows once code exists.

## 7) OpenCode Agent Integration

- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` handles git status/diff review and commits.
- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` tells parent agents when to invoke `@gitter`.
- Use `@gitter` when user asks for commit help or when changes should be grouped cleanly.

## 8) Keeping This File Fresh

- Update this file whenever build/test tooling is introduced or changed.
- Keep command examples executable and component-specific.
- If a local tool config conflicts with this file, local config wins; then patch this file.

# Dark Factory - Agent Operating Guide

This file is for coding agents working in `dark-factory`.
It reflects only what is currently true in this repository.

## 1) Current Repository Context

- The repo is early-stage and mostly docs/config right now.
- Tracked project files currently include:
  - `README.md`
  - `TODO.md`
  - `AGENTS.md`
  - `opencode.jsonc`
  - `.opencode/agents/gitter.md`
  - `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md`
- No application code tree is committed yet (`src/`, `apps/`, `crates/`, etc.).

## 2) Build/Lint/Test Status (Current Truth)

- There are no validated build, lint, typecheck, or test commands yet.
- Do not invent or assume project commands in commits or PR notes.
- If new tooling is added, document only commands that are verified in this repo.

## 3) Cursor and Copilot Rules

- Checked and currently absent:
  - `.cursor/rules/`
  - `.cursorrules`
  - `.github/copilot-instructions.md`
- If any of these files appear later, treat them as authoritative and update this guide.

## 4) Coding Style (Minimal Baseline)

Until language/tool-specific configs exist, follow pragmatic defaults:

- Favor readable, explicit code over clever shortcuts.
- Keep functions focused and avoid hidden side effects.
- Avoid dead code, unused imports, and speculative abstractions.
- Keep naming consistent (`PascalCase` types, `camelCase` values/functions, `UPPER_SNAKE_CASE` constants).
- Handle errors with context; do not swallow exceptions silently.
- Never log secrets or credentials.

## 5) Git Workflow

- Commit meaningful units of work; avoid giant mixed commits.
- Do not push unless the user explicitly requests it.
- Commit message format:
  - `{Component/Meta} // {Optional Addition} // {Short Description} (Optional,Tags)`
- Examples:
  - `Docs // Added converted PDF docs`
  - `Pipelines // ODM // Added initial ODM pipeline (WIP)`
- In commit body, add a short rationale and signature when possible:
  - `// Chappie/Model (your model if known)`

## 6) OpenCode Integration

- `.opencode/agents/gitter.md` is the git-focused subagent.
- `.opencode/skills/gitter-commit/SKILL.md` documents when to route commit tasks to `@gitter`.
- Use `@gitter` when the user asks for commit support or cleanup.

## 7) Keep This File Updated

- Update this file when real code, tooling, or CI is added.
- Keep instructions tied to verified repository behavior.
- Prefer short, accurate guidance over aspirational process docs.

- Final `git status` result
